title: Clovis Oncology Stock Is Falling After an Analyst Said a Licensing Deal Was Ill Timed
text:
Text size

One analyst has run out of patience with Clovis Oncology , a biotech firm that focuses on cancer drugs.

In a note Tuesday morning, SVB Leerink’s Andrew Berens took a hard line on the company’s decision, announced on Monday, to license a targeted radiotherapy program from a private German biotechnology company called 3B Pharmaceuticals.

The deal is “ill-timed given investor concerns about the company’s use of cash and solvency amidst an increasing mountain of convertible debt,” Berens wrote. He downgraded Clovis (ticker: CLVS) to Market Perform from Outperform, and cut his price target to $10 from $22. The stock closed at $4.59 on Monday.

Clovis didn’t immediately respond to a request for comment about the downgrade.

Editor's Choice

The back story. Shares of Clovis are down 74.5% this year. The company’s drug Rubraca, a so-called PARP inhibitor that treats ovarian cancer, is facing growing competition from offerings from AstraZeneca (AZN) and a GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) subsidiary.

What’s new. In his note, Berens said the deal, under which Clovis made a $12 million upfront payment for the rights to a preclinical radiopharmaceutical program, was a bad sign.

“While the deal to in-license a radiotherapy for [about] $12 [million] up front does not seem exorbitant and could eventually add fundamental value, it burdens Clovis with development expenses and milestones at a time when equity investors are increasingly concerned that the company is not aligned with their best interests,” Berens wrote. “Development of these programs will draw on incremental financial resources at a time when many investors remain concerned about near-term cash flows and solvency of the company.”

He also said that the deal could distract from Rubraca, and said that it suggests that a “near-term acquisition of the company is unlikely.”

His lowered price target remains 118% higher than the Monday closing price, but Berens said “current management strategies are unlikely to unlock this value in the near term.”

Looking ahead. Shares of Clovis were down 3.2% in premarket trading on Tuesday, after falling 3.3% on Monday. The stock was trading at $4.44, below its 52-week low of $4.56. S&P 500 futures were up 0.3%.

Write to Josh Nathan-Kazis at josh.nathan-kazis@barrons.com
